title: Doctor (film series)
text:
The Doctor films were developed from the <a href="Doctor%20%28novel%20series%29">series</a> of <a href="comic%20novel">comic novel</a>s by British physician <a href="Richard%20Gordon%20%28English%20author%29">Richard Gordon</a> covering the antics of a group of young doctors. The early films featured <a href="Dirk%20Bogarde">Dirk Bogarde</a> in the lead as Doctor Sparrow and <a href="Donald%20Sinden">Donald Sinden</a> as Benskin. Later films starred <a href="Leslie%20Phillips">Leslie Phillips</a>.
The films were directed by <a href="Ralph%20Thomas">Ralph Thomas</a> and produced by <a href="Betty%20Box">Betty Box</a>. The films inspired several spin-off television series.
The first film, "<a href="Doctor%20in%20the%20House">Doctor in the House</a>", was initiated by Betty Box, who picked up a copy of the book at <a href="Crewe">Crewe</a> during a long rail journey. She saw its possibility as a film, but Box and Ralph Thomas had a job convincing <a href="Rank%20Organisation">Rank</a> executives that people would go to a film about doctors, and that Bogarde, who up to then had played <a href="spiv">spiv</a>s and World War Two heroes, had sex appeal and could play light comedy. They got a low budget, and were only allowed to use available Rank contract artists.
Films.
Television series.
A successful <a href="television%20series">television series</a> "<a href="Doctor%20in%20the%20House%20%28TV%20series%29">Doctor in the House (TV)</a>", from <a href="London%20Weekend%20Television">London Weekend Television</a>, <a href="Seven%20Network">Seven Network</a> (Australia), and the <a href="British%20Broadcasting%20Corporation">British Broadcasting Corporation</a> followed.
